Description: Fragment from a tunic in undyed linen plain weave; the decoration of the neck opeing and beginning of two clavi has been applied and sewn to the plain weave; the applied piece includes plain weave in undyed linen and tapestry in dark blue wool; at the upper part of the decoration is a line of sewing holes and in one place red wool threads remain, indicating that the neck opening was highlighted with a chain? in red wool; the decoration on the breast shows five stanidng human figures, each under an arcade, from the left to the right - is a male with a skirt and a bare torso, he holds a bow? in his left hand; the second figure's wool is mainly missing and identification is difficult, the figure walks to the left and the head faces the right, the figure wears a skirt and mantle and raises the left hand; the third figure is a female and wears a long dress and a veil and holds in her raised left hand an object (fruit?); the forth figure is male and walks to the left with his head to the right, he wears a short tunic with one bare shoulder, he holds in his right hand, behind his head, a sythe and in his left hand two dead birds; the fifth figure is male in the same attitude and clothes as the first but he holds in his left hand a lyre; the five figures could be followers of Dionysis (Satyr or Mennad?) or Pan, the fourth could be a personification of Autumn, the female could be a personification of the Earth/Gaia (? for all); the main scene is framed above with a freize of medallions with alternatively floral motifs and running animals (rabbits); the main scene is framed below with a freize of a beige circles and a coloured dot in the middle; the two clavi are decorated with medallions with a male figure wearing only a mantle, the one on the right is damaged and the one on the left is wearing boots and holding two objects - sheild in the left hand and a circular object in his raised right hand, the left leg is standing on a stylised rock and the background is decorated with vine leaves; the other medallions of the clavus are alternatively decorated with feline, rabbit and vegetal motifs; edges are cut and ragged; plain weave (main cloth): warp-undyed linen (S/28), weft-undyed linen (S/15); plain weave (decorative piece): warp-undyed linen (S/30), weft-undyed linen (S/22); tapestry on grouped threads: warp-undyed linen (S/11), weft-undyed linen (S/triple/32), dark blue wool (Z/52); the background of the animals uses paired threads, one blue and one beige; flying threads: undyed linen (S/some paired); sewing: undyed linen (S spun Z ply)
Bibliographic references: Badawy 1978 / Coptic art and archaeology (4.72, p.293)
Budge 1922 / British Museum. Guide to the fourth, fifth and sixth Egyptian rooms, and the Coptic room (p.227) (Table case H, no.1)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1989 Jan-Mar, South Florida Science Museum, Imhotep's Egypt: Discovering Ancient Egyptian Technology 1989 Apr-Jun, Miami, Museum of Science, Imhotep's Egypt: Discovering Ancient Egyptian Technology 1989 Jul-Aug, Jacksonville Museum of Science History, Imhotep's Egypt: Discovering Ancient Egyptian Technology
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
